headline: European Alternatives
subtext: Discover European and open-source alternatives to US tech giants. Support digital sovereignty, data privacy, and local innovation.
nudge: This is not here to force anyone to switch, especially not immediately. It is here to show that Europe already has strong alternatives we can actually use, and that we are not behind in tech.

gdpr.title: GDPR Compliant
gdpr.description: European services built with privacy-first principles and strict data protection

sovereignty.title: Digital Sovereignty
sovereignty.description: Keep your data in Europe, under European law and jurisdiction

openSource.title: Open Source Options
openSource.description: Transparent, auditable, and community-driven software you can trust

scoreContext.title: Why some US vendors score lower
scoreContext.intro: In many cases this is structural, not personal: strong products can still carry higher trust risk because of legal jurisdiction, data-transfer exposure, and centralized data flows.

fisa.title: FISA Section 702 and EO 12333
fisa.text: US intelligence frameworks can enable broad collection on non-US persons and create legal conflict with EU privacy expectations.

cloudAct.title: CLOUD Act style legal reach
cloudAct.text: US-headquartered providers can face lawful-access demands even when customer data is stored or processed in European regions.

transfers.title: EU-US transfer complexity (DPF/SCC)
transfers.text: Transfer frameworks help operations, but they do not fully remove sovereignty, redress, or compliance uncertainty in every case.

metadata.title: Metadata remains highly revealing
metadata.text: Even with end-to-end encryption, metadata such as contacts, timing, and location-linked activity can still expose sensitive patterns.

brokeredData.title: Commercially acquired data pipelines
brokeredData.text: Public reports show agencies can also buy app/web ecosystem data from brokers, extending visibility beyond one single service.

openSource.title: Why open source often scores higher
openSource.text: Open-source software can be audited, forked, self-hosted, and hardened by independent communities. When collection is minimized and infrastructure is under your control, jurisdiction and opacity risk are reduced.

scoreContext.videoPrefix: The kickoff research video is published on

disclaimer.title: No one's perfect — and we know it
disclaimer.text: Every service listed here has its own trade-offs. Some are fully open source, others aren't. Some have had incidents in the past, others are simply young and unproven. We encourage you to do your own research. The goal isn't to present a flawless list — it's to show that credible European options exist.

communityNote.prefix: We are trying hard to keep this list accurate, but mistakes can happen. If you find one, please open an issue in our repository
communityNote.suffix: and we will do our best to correct the information as soon as possible.
